roadmap.title: Our roadmap
roadmap.subtitle: As a fully open-source project, we're always looking for ways to improve Director. Here's what we're working on next.

1.title: Stable MVP (11.07.25)
1.description: Release a robust MVP that allows for anyone to get started with MCP without needing our assistance.

2.title: Filtering
2.description: Allow users to filter any MCP server's functionality (tools, resources, etc) by name across our SDK, CLI, and Studio.

3.title: OAUTH
3.description: Introduce full oAuth support for MCP servers, allowing users to authenticate with any MCP server using their existing credentials.

4.title: Transforms
4.description: Add support for transforming the signature (e.g., the description of a tool) of any MCP server functionality across our SDK, CLI, and Studio.

5.title: Middleware
5.description: Add first-class support for middleware, allowing users to add custom logic to the MCP server's functionality across our SDK, CLI, and Studio.

6.title: Deployment
6.description: Allow users to deploy their toolsets to the cloud and connect from any where, any time.

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.subtitle: Director is a local first MCP gateway that makes it easy to extend your favorite AI applications and agents capabilities using MCP.

cli.label: CLI
cli.title: Run the MCP gateway locally
cli.description: Director's command line interface (CLI) allows you to run your own MCP gateway, setup multiple MCP servers, and connect them to any MCP client. All 100% locally on your machine.

studio.label: Studio
studio.title: Configure in your browser
studio.description: Director Studio allows you to configure your MCP gateway straight from your favorite browser. Say goodbye to complex config files and start benefiting from the power of MCP today.

gateway.label: Gateway
gateway.title: Improve your toolsets
gateway.description: Our gateway is designed to work seamlessly with any MCP client or server. Director gives you the insights and tools to take full advantage of MCP today without custom integrations.

cloud.label: Cloud
cloud.title: Deploy to the cloud
cloud.description: Deploy your production ready MCP gateway to the cloud securely and with ease. Enable your whole team to leverage the full power of MCP while maintaining governance over usage and your data.

useCases.title: Get actual work done with MCP.
useCases.subtitle: Create separate proxies for each of your tasks so that your models can easily find the right tool for the job. Less confusion, less errors, more results.

sales.title: Automate lead nurturing
sales.description: Use natural language to take a lead from cold to warm. Ask your favorite AI tools to enrich a profile, add it to your CRM, draft an email, and send it. It's that simple. Just connect Director to your existing tools like Hubspot, Attio, and Resend.

support.title: Speed up support
support.description: Save time by using Director to help answer support requests. Connect to tools like Stripe to solve billing problems, Intercom to draft and send on-brand messages, or use Context7 to look up technical documentation and provide accurate solutions.

engineering.title: Fix bugs as they happen
engineering.description: Fix bugs in real time with Director. Use your favorite LLM to automatically take a bug report, draft a plan based on your codebase, update the issue ticket, and create a pull request with the fix. Simply by connecting to tools like Sentry, Linear, and Github.

product.title: Ship at speed
product.description: Improve your shipping velocity by using Director to automate your product process. Use your preferred LLM to read customer feedback, create and triage tickets, and draft plans for features and improvements. It's as easy as connecting tools like Linear, Intercom, and Notion.

whatIsMCP.title: What is MCP?
whatIsMCP.subtitle: MCP (Model Context Protocol) is a standard way for AI applications and agents to connect to and work with your data sources and tools. You can think of it as a universal adapter for AI applications, similar to what USB-C is for physical devices or oAuth is for authentication.

1.title: What is Model Context Protocol?
1.description:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a standard way for AI applications and agents to connect to and work with your data sources, tools, and applications.

It's been described as the "USB-C for AI" as it provides a universal way to connect LLMs to resources they can use. Prior to USB-C, you needed loads of different cables for different devices. Similarly, prior to MCP, you needed to build custom integrations to each resource you wanted your AI application to use.

You can also think of them as APIs that are specially designed for LLMs.

2.title: What is the MCP protocol, client, and server?
2.description:
MCP consists of three main components to create bridge between your AI applications and the resources they need.

- **MCP servers** provide access to data sources and tools through a well-defined interface.
- **MCP clients** connect to MCP servers and request resources/actions on behalf of your AI application.
- **MCP protocol** defines the standardized message format for communication between MCP servers and clients. This includes handling tool discovery, authentication, and response handling.

Letâ€™s look at an example:

1. You ask Claude Desktop (MCP Client) to summarize your meeting notes from Notion.
2. Claude Desktop connects to Notion via it's MCP Server to discover the available tools and resources. The client then requests the resource it's looking for using the tools at it's disposal.
3. Notion (MCP Server) responds with the content of the requested resource and Claude Desktop is able to create it's summary for the request.

3.title: What are the capabilities of MCP?
3.description:
Both MCP clients and servers offer different capabilities.

**MCP servers** provide the fundamental blocks for adding context to your AI applications. The following capabilities allow for powerful interactions between clients, servers and LLMs:

- **Prompts** are templates that can be used to generate text or other content.
- **Tools** are pre-built functions that can be used to perform specific tasks.
- **Resources** are data sources that can be used to provide context to your AI application.

**MCP clients** provide access to MCP servers and request resources/actions on behalf of your AI application. They also expose the following capabilities:

- **Roots** allow MCP servers to understand which directories and files they have access to in a filesystem.
- **Sampling** allows MCP servers to request LLM completions or generations via MCP clients.
 - **Elicitation** allows an MCP server to request additional information from users through an MCP Client.

4.title: What are the benefits for AI users?
4.description:
MCP enables AI applications to access your personal data and tools, like Google Drive documents or GitHub repositories, making them more helpful and contextually relevant. Instead of being limited to general knowledge, AI can now understand your specific work context and provide personalized assistance.

For example, an AI assistant could read your meeting notes from Notion and automatically schedule follow-ups using your calendar, all through MCP-powered connections.

5.title: What are the benefits for developers?
5.description:
MCP streamlines development by eliminating the need for custom, one-off connectors to various data sources. Developers can leverage reusable, open source MCP servers, like those for Google Drive or Slack, saving time and reducing complexity.

This shared ecosystem allows developers to focus on building innovative AI experiences, while easily integrating with the tools and data sources their users already use.
